Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Situation2: A patient with a chronic autoimmune disease requires a very specific and ongoing treatment plan.
Story:
My phone buzzed with a reminder: “Call Mom and Dad.” Every Sunday evening, I set aside time to talk to them, to hear about their week, to reassure them that I was taking care of myself. They worried about me, living alone in the city, working long hours at the hospital. I knew how much these calls meant to them, and to me too—I missed their voices, their gentle questions, their laughter.

But tonight, as I glanced at the clock, I was still at my desk, reviewing the chart of a patient with a rare autoimmune disease. She needed a precise combination of medications, and her symptoms had changed suddenly. I was the only doctor on call, and the pharmacy was waiting for my updated prescription. If I delayed, her treatment could be compromised.

My phone buzzed again. I felt the weight of my parents’ expectations, their hope for a daughter who remembered to call, who cared. At the same time, I felt the responsibility of my patient, relying on me to make the right decision, right now. My heart pounded as I stared at the phone, torn between two worlds that both needed me.
